situation: Your laptop suddenly stops working mid-semester. You need one for assignments. What do you do?

choices.text: Buy a brand-new high-end laptop ($2,000)
Buy a reliable refurbished laptop ($1,000)
Repair your current laptop ($250)
Put a new laptop on your credit card ($2,000 + interest)

situation: Your roommate says they're short on rent and asks you to cover their share this month ($650).

choices.text: Cover the full $650 with no questions
Say no and tell them to figure it out
Cover part of it ($250) and they find the rest
Cover $650 but only with a written repayment plan

situation: You and your friends are meeting downtown. You need to choose how to get there and back.

choices.text: Take TTC both ways ($6.60)
Take Uber both ways ($40)
Take TTC there and Uber back ($23)
Carpool with a friend and split gas ($12)

situation: Your bank offers to increase your credit limit from $1,000 to $3,000.

choices.text: Accept it and keep spending the same as before
Accept it and start spending more because you 'can'
Decline it because higher limits are 'dangerous'
Accept it and lower utilization by paying earlier

situation: You get a text saying 'CRA: You are eligible for a refund. Click this link to deposit $243.18.'

choices.text: Click the link and enter your banking info
Don't click it, check your CRA account directly
Reply asking if it's real
Forward the message to a friend to ask what they think
